title: R46016
content: The report provides a regional snapshot of the political climate in Latin America and the Caribbean, based on the U.S. Department of State's descriptions and NGO indices measuring democracy trends worldwide. Congress is interested in the trajectory of democracy globally and its promotion aligns with U.S. interests. For more information on global democracy trends, refer to CRS Report R45344 by Michael A. Weber. The report compiles information on the political climate in Latin America and the Caribbean from the U.S. State Department and NGO indices measuring democracy trends worldwide. Congress is interested in promoting democracy globally, as outlined in CRS Report R45344 by Michael A. Weber. The Bertelsmann Transformation Index (BTI) evaluates the quality of democracy, market economy, and political management in 129 developing and transition countries. The index is published biannually by Bertelsmann Stiftung and provides key regional findings and country reports. The Bertelsmann Transformation Index (BTI) ranks countries in developing and transition countries based on 18 indicators grouped into five criteria for political transformation. BTI assigns categories like democracy in consolidation, defective democracy, and autocracy. The index notes a decline in democracy quality in Latin America since 2008. The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) produces a democracy index annually. The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) produces a democracy index annually for 165 independent states and two territories, classifying countries as full democracies, flawed democracies, hybrid regimes, or authoritarian regimes based on 60 indicators in five categories. In the Latin America and Caribbean region, the overall score decreased from 6.26 in 2017 to 6.24 in 2018. Uruguay and Costa Rica are full democracies, while Nicaragua joined Venezuela and Cuba as authoritarian regimes in 2018. Freedom House, a U.S.-based NGO, evaluates democracy, political freedom, and human rights worldwide through its Freedom in the World report. It assigns countries points on 25 indicators, determining ratings for political rights and civil liberties on a scale of 1 to 7. Nicaragua experienced the greatest decline in the world according to the 2018 report. The 2018 report by Freedom House found Nicaragua had the greatest decline in political rights and civil liberties worldwide. Venezuela also had a significant decline, with Brazil, El Salvador, and Guatemala in the top 20. The report ranks democracy for 197 countries and 15 territories, with Uruguay, Barbados, and Chile having the highest scores in Latin America and the Caribbean, while Nicaragua, Venezuela, and Cuba had the lowest scores. V-Dem's Democracy Report 2019 evaluates 179 countries, categorizing them into liberal democracy, electoral democracy, electoral autocracy, and closed autocracy. The report notes a decline in Latin America's democracy levels in 2018. V-Dem evaluates Central and South American nations, excluding Caribbean nations except for a few. Table 1 shows global democracy rankings for Caribbean countries according to various indexes. According to various democracy indexes such as EIU's Democracy Index 2018, Freedom House's Freedom in the World 2019, V-Dem's Democracy Report 2019, and Bertelsmann Stiftung's 2018 Transformation Index, countries in Central and South America are evaluated. Tables compare rankings for Mexico and Central America, as well as South America. Figures show global ranks and classifications based on different indexes for these regions. Countries in Central and South America are evaluated based on democracy indicators from various indexes such as Freedom House's Freedom in the World 2019 and the Varieties of Democracy Institute's Democracy Report 2019. The scores range from 0 to 100 on 25 indicators, with rankings showing political rights, civil liberties, and liberal democracy classifications. Additional resources for democracy indicators in the region are provided in Table 4.
